canonical_explanation.text: Amines are derivatives of ammonia in which one or more hydrogen atoms are replaced by alkyl or aryl groups. They are classified as primary (RNH2), secondary (R2NH), and tertiary (R3N). Amines are basic because the lone pair on nitrogen can accept a proton. The basicity of aliphatic amines is generally greater than that of aromatic amines because the lone pair in aniline is delocalised into the benzene ring. Key preparation methods include reduction of nitro compounds, ammonolysis of alkyl halides, Gabriel phthalimide synthesis, and Hoffmann bromamide degradation. Diazonium salts (ArN2+X-) are prepared from primary aromatic amines by treatment with NaNO2/HCl at 0-5 degrees C and are versatile intermediates for synthesising various aromatic compounds through Sandmeyer and related reactions.
rules: Basicity order in aqueous solution: secondary aliphatic > primary aliphatic > tertiary aliphatic > NH3 > aniline (due to balance of inductive effect, solvation, and steric effects).
Gabriel phthalimide synthesis is used to prepare primary amines only; it cannot prepare secondary or tertiary amines.
Diazonium salts undergo coupling reactions with phenols (in alkaline medium) and amines to form brightly coloured azo compounds used as dyes.

questions.question_text: An amine in which the nitrogen atom is bonded to two alkyl groups and one hydrogen is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: A secondary amine is an amine in which the nitrogen atom is bonded to two alkyl groups and one hydrogen atom, which matches the description in the question.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Secondary amine. Primary amines have the nitrogen atom bonded to one alkyl group and two hydrogen atoms. Tertiary amines have the nitrogen atom bonded to three alkyl groups. Quaternary ammonium salts have the nitrogen atom bonded to four alkyl or aryl groups.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of C6H5NH2 is:
questions.explanation_correct: The IUPAC name of C6H5NH2 is phenylamine, also known as aniline. This is because the compound has a benzene ring (C6H5-) and an amino group (NH2) attached to it, which corresponds to the structure and naming of aniline.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct. Aminobenzene is another name for aniline, but it is not the IUPAC name. Benzylamine has the formula C6H5CH2NH2, which is different from the given compound. Nitrobenzene has the formula C6H5NO2, which is a different compound with a nitro group instead of an amino group.

questions.question_text: Amines have higher boiling points than hydrocarbons of similar molecular mass because of:
questions.explanation_correct: Amines have higher boiling points than hydrocarbons of similar molecular mass because the N-H bond in amines can form hydrogen bonds, which require more energy to break compared to the weaker van der Waals forces in hydrocarbons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amines do not have ionic or metallic bonding, so options A and C are incorrect. While covalent bonding is present, the higher boiling point of amines is specifically due to the formation of hydrogen bonds involving the N-H group, not just covalent bonding alone (option D).

questions.question_text: The Gabriel phthalimide synthesis is used to prepare:
questions.explanation_correct: The Gabriel phthalimide synthesis is used to prepare primary amines only. This is because the reaction involves the nucleophilic attack of ammonia on the phthalimide group, which displaces the phthalimide group and results in the formation of a primary amine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Gabriel phthalimide synthesis cannot be used to prepare secondary or tertiary amines. This is because the reaction involves the nucleophilic attack of ammonia, which can only displace the phthalimide group to form a primary amine. To prepare secondary or tertiary amines, other methods such as the reaction of alkyl halides with ammonia or amines would be required.

questions.question_text: The Hoffmann bromamide degradation converts an amide to an amine with:

options.text: The same number of carbon atoms
One less carbon atom than the parent amide

questions.explanation_correct: The Hoffmann bromamide degradation reaction converts an amide to an amine with one less carbon atom than the parent amide. This is because the reaction involves the replacement of the carbonyl carbon with a primary amine group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Hoffmann bromamide degradation does not convert the amide to an amine with the same number of carbon atoms, one more carbon atom, or two less carbon atoms. It specifically converts the amide to an amine with one less carbon atom than the parent amide.

questions.question_text: Primary amines can be prepared from nitro compounds by reduction using:
questions.explanation_correct: Primary amines can be prepared from nitro compounds by reduction using Sn/HCl or Fe/HCl or H2/Pd. This is because the nitro group (–NO2) is reduced to an amino group (–NH2) in this process, converting the nitro compound into a primary amine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not reduce the nitro group to an amino group. KMnO4 is an oxidizing agent, concentrated H2SO4 is not a reducing agent, and NaOH is a base that does not reduce nitro compounds.

questions.question_text: Aniline is a weaker base than methylamine because:

options.text: Aniline has a higher molecular weight
The lone pair on nitrogen in aniline is delocalised into the benzene ring
Aniline has no lone pair on nitrogen

questions.explanation_correct: The lone pair on the nitrogen atom in aniline is delocalised into the benzene ring, making it less available for protonation. This reduces the basicity of aniline compared to methylamine, which has a more localised lone pair on the nitrogen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aniline has a lower basicity than methylamine because the lone pair on the nitrogen atom in aniline is delocalised into the benzene ring, reducing its availability for protonation. The molecular weight and aromaticity of the compounds are not factors that affect their basicity.

questions.question_text: The carbylamine reaction (isocyanide test) is a test for:
questions.explanation_correct: The carbylamine reaction, also known as the isocyanide test, is a test specifically for primary amines. This is because the reaction involves the formation of an isocyanide (R-N=C) group, which can only occur when a primary amine (RNH2) reacts with chloroform (CHCl3) in the presence of a strong base.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The carbylamine reaction is not a test for all amines, secondary amines, or tertiary amines. This is because the mechanism of the reaction requires a primary amine (RNH2) to form the characteristic isocyanide product. Secondary (R2NH) and tertiary (R3N) amines do not undergo this reaction, as they lack the necessary primary amine structure.

questions.question_text: When a primary aliphatic amine reacts with nitrous acid (NaNO2/HCl), it gives:

options.text: An alcohol with evolution of N2 gas

questions.explanation_correct: When a primary aliphatic amine reacts with nitrous acid (NaNO2/HCl), it undergoes a reaction called the Diazo reaction, which results in the formation of an alcohol and the evolution of nitrogen gas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because diazonium salts are formed from primary aromatic amines, not aliphatic amines. Option C is incorrect because nitrosoamines are formed when a secondary amine reacts with nitrous acid. Option D is incorrect because a primary aliphatic amine does indeed react with nitrous acid to produce an alcohol and nitrogen gas.

questions.question_text: Acylation of amines (reaction with acid chlorides) gives:
questions.explanation_correct: The reaction of amines with acid chlorides gives amides, which are the correct answer. Amides are formed when the nitrogen atom of the amine group replaces the hydroxyl group (-OH) of the carboxylic acid, creating a new C-N bond.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because acylation of amines does not produce an alcohol, ester, or nitrile. Alcohols are formed by the reduction of carbonyl compounds, esters are formed by the reaction of carboxylic acids and alcohols, and nitriles are formed by the dehydration of amides. The correct product of the acylation of amines is an amide.

questions.question_text: When a secondary amine reacts with nitrous acid, it gives:
questions.explanation_correct: When a secondary amine reacts with nitrous acid (HNO2), it undergoes a nitrosation reaction to form an N-nitrosoamine, which is an oily yellow compound. This is because the lone pair on the nitrogen atom of the secondary amine can be protonated by the nitrous acid, leading to the formation of the N-nitrosoamine product.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because diazonium salts are formed from primary aromatic amines, not secondary amines. Option C is incorrect because the reaction of a secondary amine with nitrous acid does not produce an alcohol. Option D is incorrect because a reaction does occur between a secondary amine and nitrous acid, resulting in the formation of an N-nitrosoamine.

questions.question_text: Diazonium salts are prepared from primary aromatic amines by treating with NaNO2 and HCl at:
questions.explanation_correct: Diazonium salts are prepared from primary aromatic amines by treating with NaNO2 and HCl at 0-5 degrees C because this low temperature is necessary to keep the diazonium salts stable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is option B, 0-5 degrees C. Diazonium salts are unstable at room temperature and will decompose rapidly, so the reaction needs to be carried out at a low temperature of 0-5 degrees C to maintain the stability of the diazonium salt. The other temperature options like 100 degrees C or -50 degrees C are not suitable for this reaction.

questions.question_text: In the Sandmeyer reaction, the diazonium salt reacts with CuCl/HCl to give:
questions.explanation_correct: In the Sandmeyer reaction, the diazonium salt reacts with CuCl/HCl to produce a chloro-substituted aromatic compound, such as chlorobenzene. This substitution reaction occurs because the chloride ion from CuCl/HCl replaces the diazonium group on the aromatic ring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Sandmeyer reaction does not produce bromobenzene, phenol, or fluorobenzene. These products would require different reaction conditions or starting materials. The key step in the Sandmeyer reaction is the substitution of the diazonium group with a chloride ion, leading to the formation of chlorobenzene as the final product.

questions.question_text: The coupling reaction of a diazonium salt with phenol in alkaline medium gives:
questions.explanation_correct: The coupling reaction of a diazonium salt with phenol in alkaline medium gives an azo dye, which is a brightly colored compound. This is because the electrophilic diazonium ion (ArN2+) reacts with the nucleophilic phenoxide ion to form the stable azo compound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (a nitroso compound) is incorrect because the reaction of a diazonium salt with phenol does not produce a nitroso compound. Option C (a nitro compound) is incorrect because the reaction does not involve the introduction of a nitro group. Option D (an amide) is incorrect because the reaction does not involve the formation of an amide group.

questions.question_text: The Balz-Schiemann reaction of a diazonium salt gives:
questions.explanation_correct: The Balz-Schiemann reaction involves the treatment of a diazonium salt with fluoroboric acid to produce a fluoroarene. This reaction is a useful way to prepare fluorobenzene derivatives from the corresponding anilines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Balz-Schiemann reaction does not produce chlorobenzene, iodobenzene, or phenol. Chlorobenzene is obtained by the Sandmeyer reaction, which involves treatment of a diazonium salt with copper(I) chloride. Iodobenzene is obtained by the Sandmeyer reaction using copper(I) iodide. Phenol is not a product of the Balz-Schiemann reaction, which specifically introduces a fluorine atom onto the aromatic ring.

questions.question_text: In the Hinsberg test, primary amines react with benzenesulfonyl chloride to give a product that is:

options.text: Soluble in NaOH (because the sulfonamide has an acidic N-H)

questions.explanation_correct: The Hinsberg test involves the reaction of primary amines with benzenesulfonyl chloride. The product of this reaction is a sulfonamide, which has an acidic N-H bond. This makes the sulfonamide soluble in NaOH, as the N-H proton can be removed to form a negatively charged species.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In the Hinsberg test, primary amines react with benzenesulfonyl chloride to form a sulfonamide product. This sulfonamide is soluble in NaOH because the N-H bond is acidic, not insoluble, not a gas, and not coloured. The correct option is B, as the sulfonamide can be dissolved in NaOH due to the acidic nature of the N-H group.

questions.question_text: Among methylamine, dimethylamine, trimethylamine, and ammonia, the order of basic strength in aqueous solution is:
questions.explanation_correct: The order of basic strength in aqueous solution is (CH3)2NH > CH3NH2 > (CH3)3N > NH3. This is because as the number of alkyl groups (CH3) attached to the nitrogen increases, the electron density around the nitrogen increases, making it more able to donate the lone pair and accept a proton, i.e., more basic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the order of increasing basic strength is not (CH3)3N > (CH3)2NH > CH3NH2 > NH3. This is because as the number of alkyl groups attached to the nitrogen increases, the electron density around the nitrogen increases, making it more able to donate the lone pair and accept a proton, i.e., more basic. Therefore, the correct order is (CH3)2NH > CH3NH2 > (CH3)3N > NH3.

questions.question_text: The reduction of a nitrile (R-CN) with LiAlH4 or H2/Ni gives:
questions.explanation_correct: The reduction of a nitrile (R-CN) with LiAlH4 or H2/Ni reduces the nitrile group to a primary amine (R-CH2NH2), since the nitrile group is converted to an imine intermediate which is then further reduced to the primary amine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reduction of a nitrile does not produce a secondary amine (R2NH), a carboxylic acid (R-COOH), or an aldehyde (R-CHO). These are different products that would result from other types of reactions, not the reduction of a nitrile group. The correct product is a primary amine (R-CH2NH2) formed by the reduction of the nitrile.

questions.question_text: When a diazonium salt is treated with water (warming), it gives:
questions.explanation_correct: When a diazonium salt (ArN2+X-) is treated with water and warmed, it undergoes a diazo coupling reaction to form phenol with the release of nitrogen gas. This is because the diazonium group is replaced by a hydroxyl group, forming the phenol product.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Treating a diazonium salt with water does not produce chlorobenzene, benzene, or aniline. Chlorobenzene requires a Sandmeyer reaction with a copper(I) chloride reagent. Benzene is a different aromatic compound not formed in this reaction. Aniline is the starting material for the diazonium salt, not the product of this reaction.

questions.question_text: Ammonolysis of an alkyl halide with excess NH3 gives primarily:

options.text: A mixture of primary, secondary, tertiary amines and quaternary salt

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is D because the ammonolysis of an alkyl halide with excess ammonia can give a mixture of primary, secondary, tertiary amines and a quaternary salt. This is because the initial nucleophilic substitution can be followed by further reactions of the amine products with the alkyl halide, forming the different amine types and the quaternary salt.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not account for the excess ammonia and the potential for further reactions. Option A (tertiary amine) is incorrect because the initial substitution would give a primary amine, which can then undergo further reactions. Option B (secondary amine) is incorrect because the initial product is a primary amine, and option C (primary amine) is incomplete as it does not consider the potential for further reactions with the excess ammonia.

questions.question_text: Aniline does not undergo Friedel-Crafts reaction directly because:

options.text: The -NH2 group acts as a base and forms salt with the Lewis acid catalyst AlCl3, deactivating the ring

questions.explanation_correct: The -NH2 group in aniline acts as a base and forms a salt with the Lewis acid catalyst AlCl3, deactivating the benzene ring and preventing the Friedel-Crafts reaction from occurring directly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aniline does not undergo Friedel-Crafts reaction directly because the -NH2 group is a strong base that forms a salt with the AlCl3 catalyst, preventing it from activating the benzene ring. This deactivates the ring and makes it unreactive towards electrophilic aromatic substitution. The other options are incorrect because aniline is aromatic, has pi-electrons, and is not too bulky for the reaction.

questions.question_text: Aniline is acetylated (acylated) before carrying out nitration to:

options.text: Increase the yield of meta product
Protect the amino group from oxidation and control the reaction to give mainly the para product

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B. Acetylating aniline (adding an acetyl group) protects the amino group from oxidation, which allows the nitration reaction to proceed mainly to the para position rather than giving a mixture of products.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: A) Acetylation does not increase the yield of the meta product, it controls the reaction to give mainly the para product. C) Acetylation does not increase the rate of the reaction, it protects the amino group. D) Acetylation does not convert aniline to a gas, it is a liquid organic compound.

questions.question_text: When benzenediazonium chloride is treated with CuCN/KCN, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: When benzenediazonium chloride (ArN2+Cl-) is treated with CuCN/KCN, it undergoes a Sandmeyer reaction to produce cyanobenzene (benzonitrile, ArCN), which is the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) Chlorobenzene is not the product of this reaction, C) Phenol is not formed, and D) Nitrobenzene is also not the product. The Sandmeyer reaction specifically converts the diazonium group (ArN2+) to a cyano group (ArCN).

questions.question_text: The Hoffmann bromamide reaction of acetamide (CH3CONH2) with Br2/NaOH gives:
questions.explanation_correct: The Hoffmann bromamide reaction of acetamide (CH3CONH2) with Br2/NaOH produces methylamine (CH3NH2), which is a primary amine. This is because the Hoffmann reaction involves the conversion of a primary amide to a primary amine through the rearrangement of the amide group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Methylamine. In the Hoffmann bromamide reaction, the acetamide (CH3CONH2) undergoes rearrangement to produce methylamine (CH3NH2), which is a primary amine. The other options, such as ethylamine, acetic acid, and acetonitrile, are not the products of this specific reaction.

questions.question_text: Aniline reacts with bromine water to give:
questions.explanation_correct: Aniline, being an aromatic amine, undergoes electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions. When treated with bromine water, it forms 2,4,6-tribromoaniline as the major product, which is a white precipitate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not represent the major product of the reaction. 2-Bromoaniline, 3-bromoaniline, and 4-bromoaniline are possible mono-substituted products, but the reaction favors the formation of the tri-substituted 2,4,6-tribromoaniline due to the high reactivity of the aromatic ring towards electrophilic substitution.

questions.question_text: Diazonium salts are important in synthesis because they allow the introduction of groups like -OH, -X, -CN, -NO2 on the benzene ring by replacing:
questions.explanation_correct: Diazonium salts contain the -N2+ group, which is a reactive electrophilic species. This group can be replaced by other nucleophilic groups like -OH, -X, -CN, -NO2 to introduce these substituents onto the benzene ring, making diazonium salts versatile intermediates for organic synthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diazonium group (-N2+) is the key reactive part that allows for substitution reactions on the benzene ring. Replacing a hydrogen atom, an alkyl group, or the entire benzene ring would not allow for the selective introduction of the desired functional groups that diazonium salts enable. The diazonium group is the crucial component that makes these salts useful synthetic intermediates.

questions.question_text: The -NH2 group on a benzene ring is:
questions.explanation_correct: The -NH2 group on a benzene ring is an activating and ortho/para-directing group. This is because the lone pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom can donate electron density to the benzene ring, making it more electron-rich and therefore more reactive towards electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions. The -NH2 group also directs incoming substituents to the ortho and para positions on the ring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The -NH2 group on a benzene ring is not deactivating and meta-directing. The presence of the -NH2 group actually activates the benzene ring towards electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions, making it more reactive. Additionally, the -NH2 group directs incoming substituents to the ortho and para positions, not the meta position.

questions.question_text: p-Toluidine is a stronger base than aniline because the methyl group:

options.text: Is electron-donating (+I effect) which increases electron density on nitrogen

questions.explanation_correct: The methyl group in p-toluidine is electron-donating (+I effect), which increases the electron density on the nitrogen atom. This makes the lone pair on nitrogen more available for proton acceptance, increasing the basicity of p-toluidine compared to aniline.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the methyl group is electron-donating, not electron-withdrawing. Option C is incorrect because the methyl group does have an effect on the basicity of p-toluidine. Option D is incorrect because increased steric hindrance would actually decrease the basicity of p-toluidine, not increase it.

questions.question_text: When benzenediazonium chloride is treated with H3PO2 and water, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: When benzenediazonium chloride is treated with hypophosphorous acid (H3PO2) and water, the diazonium group is replaced by hydrogen, resulting in the formation of benzene as the product.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A, phenol, is incorrect because phenol is formed when benzenediazonium chloride is treated with water and phenol. Option C, chlorobenzene, is incorrect because chlorobenzene is formed when benzenediazonium chloride is treated with copper(I) chloride. Option D, biphenyl, is incorrect because biphenyl is formed when benzenediazonium chloride is treated with copper(I) chloride and benzene.

questions.question_text: Lower aliphatic amines are soluble in water because:

options.text: They can form hydrogen bonds with water
They have low molecular weight only

questions.explanation_correct: Lower aliphatic amines are soluble in water because they can form hydrogen bonds with water molecules. The lone pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom of the amine can act as a hydrogen bond acceptor, allowing the amine to interact with the hydrogen atoms of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lower aliphatic amines are not ionic, as they do not have a positive or negative charge. They also have a relatively low molecular weight, but this is not the primary reason for their solubility in water. The amines are polar molecules, with the nitrogen atom being partially negatively charged, which allows them to form hydrogen bonds with water and become soluble.

questions.question_text: In the carbylamine reaction, a primary amine reacts with CHCl3 and KOH to give a foul-smelling:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B. In the carbylamine reaction, a primary amine reacts with chloroform (CHCl3) and potassium hydroxide (KOH) to produce a foul-smelling isocyanide (also called a carbylamine), which has the characteristic R-N≡C structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because the carbylamine reaction does not produce a carboxylic acid (A), a nitrile (C), or an aldehyde (D). The carbylamine reaction is a specific reaction that forms an isocyanide, which has a characteristic unpleasant odor.

questions.question_text: p-Nitroaniline is a much weaker base than aniline because the nitro group:

options.text: Withdraws electron density from the ring and nitrogen through -I and -M effects

questions.explanation_correct: The nitro group (-NO2) is an electron-withdrawing group that reduces the electron density on the benzene ring and the nitrogen atom in p-nitroaniline. This decreases the basicity of the amine, making it a weaker base compared to aniline.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nitro group does not increase electron density on the nitrogen atom. Instead, it withdraws electrons from the ring and the nitrogen through both inductive (-I) and mesomeric (-M) effects, decreasing the basicity of the amine. The correct option is B, which accurately describes the electronic effects of the nitro group.

questions.question_text: The process of converting a primary aromatic amine into a diazonium salt is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The process of converting a primary aromatic amine into a diazonium salt is called diazotisation. This is a key reaction where the primary aromatic amine is treated with sodium nitrite (NaNO2) and hydrochloric acid (HCl) at low temperature (0-5°C) to form a diazonium salt, which is a reactive intermediate used for further synthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is diazotisation. Dimerisation refers to the formation of a compound with two identical units, deamination is the removal of an amino group, and dehydration is the removal of water. None of these terms accurately describe the process of converting a primary aromatic amine into a diazonium salt, which is the key step in the diazotisation reaction.

questions.question_text: Methylamine reacts with excess methyl iodide to give eventually:
questions.explanation_correct: Methylamine (CH3NH2) reacts with excess methyl iodide (CH3I) to form tetramethylammonium iodide (CH3)4N+I-, the correct answer. This happens through a series of alkylation reactions, where the hydrogen atoms on the amine group are sequentially replaced by methyl groups.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: A) Dimethylamine (CH3)2NH is an intermediate product, not the final product. B) Trimethylamine (CH3)3N is also an intermediate product, not the final product. D) Methylamine does in fact react with excess methyl iodide, forming the final product tetramethylammonium iodide.

questions.question_text: When benzenediazonium chloride is treated with KI, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: When benzenediazonium chloride is treated with potassium iodide (KI), the diazo group (-N2+) is replaced by an iodine atom, resulting in the formation of iodobenzene. This is a classic Sandmeyer reaction, where the diazonium salt undergoes a nucleophilic substitution with the iodide ion to produce the iodinated aromatic compound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not represent the product formed when benzenediazonium chloride is treated with KI. Fluorobenzene, chlorobenzene, and bromobenzene would be the products if the diazo group was replaced by fluorine, chlorine, or bromine, respectively, instead of iodine. The Sandmeyer reaction specifically involves the replacement of the diazo group with an iodine atom, leading to the formation of iodobenzene as the correct answer.

questions.question_text: The Gabriel phthalimide synthesis can be used to prepare both primary and secondary amines.
questions.explanation_correct: The Gabriel phthalimide synthesis can only be used to prepare primary amines, not secondary amines. This method involves the reaction of an alkyl halide with potassium phthalimide, which displaces the halide to form an N-alkylphthalimide. This is then hydrolysed to release the primary amine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Gabriel phthalimide synthesis cannot be used to prepare secondary amines. This method involves the reaction of an alkyl halide with potassium phthalimide, which displaces the halide to form an N-alkylphthalimide. This is then hydrolysed to release the primary amine. To prepare secondary amines, other methods like the reductive amination of aldehydes and ketones or the reaction of primary amines with alkyl halides would be needed.

questions.question_text: Aromatic amines are stronger bases than aliphatic amines.
questions.explanation_correct: Aromatic amines are generally weaker bases than aliphatic amines because the lone pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom in aromatic amines is delocalized into the benzene ring, making them less available for protonation. In contrast, the lone pair in aliphatic amines is more localized, making them stronger bases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement that aromatic amines are stronger bases than aliphatic amines is incorrect. This is because the lone pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom in aromatic amines is delocalized into the benzene ring, making it less available for protonation and thus reducing the basicity of the aromatic amine. In contrast, the lone pair in aliphatic amines is more localized, making them stronger bases.

questions.question_text: Diazonium salts of aliphatic amines are very stable and easily isolated.
questions.explanation_correct: Diazonium salts of aliphatic amines are not very stable and cannot be easily isolated. This is because the R-N≡N+ group in aliphatic diazonium salts is highly unstable and readily decomposes, unlike the more stable aromatic diazonium salts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diazonium salts are prepared from primary aromatic amines, not aliphatic amines. Aliphatic amines do not form stable diazonium salts because the R-N≡N+ group in aliphatic diazonium salts is highly unstable and readily decomposes, unlike the more stable aromatic diazonium salts. Therefore, the statement that diazonium salts of aliphatic amines are very stable and easily isolated is false.

questions.question_text: The carbylamine reaction is used to test for primary amines specifically.
questions.explanation_correct: The carbylamine reaction is a test used specifically to identify primary amines. In this reaction, a primary amine reacts with chloroform (CHCl3) and a strong base like potassium hydroxide (KOH) to form a foul-smelling compound called an isocyanide or carbylamine. This reaction helps distinguish primary amines from secondary and tertiary amines, which do not undergo this test.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The carbylamine reaction is not used to test for secondary or tertiary amines. These types of amines do not have a hydrogen atom attached directly to the nitrogen, which is required for the carbylamine reaction to occur. Instead, the carbylamine reaction is a specific test for the presence of primary amines, where one of the substituents on the nitrogen is a hydrogen atom.

questions.question_text: Azo coupling reactions of diazonium salts occur at the para position of the phenol or amine coupling partner preferentially.
questions.explanation_correct: The azo coupling reaction of a diazonium salt with a phenol or amine compound preferentially occurs at the para position. This is because the para position is the most reactive and favored site for the electrophilic diazonium ion to attack the nucleophilic coupling partner.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be that the azo coupling reaction does not occur preferentially at the para position. This is wrong because the para position is the most reactive site for the electrophilic diazonium ion to attack the nucleophilic coupling partner, leading to the favored formation of the para-substituted azo compound.

questions.question_text: The Hoffmann bromamide degradation converts an amide (RCONH2) to a primary amine (RNH2) with ___ fewer carbon atom(s).
questions.explanation_correct: The Hoffmann bromamide degradation converts an amide (RCONH2) to a primary amine (RNH2) with one fewer carbon atom. This is because the reaction involves the removal of the carbonyl carbon from the amide, resulting in a primary amine with one less carbon than the original amide.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'one', which is correct. The Hoffmann bromamide degradation reaction removes the carbonyl carbon from the amide, resulting in a primary amine with one fewer carbon atom. Therefore, the answer is 'one', not 'two' or any other number.

questions.question_text: The basicity of amines is due to the presence of a ___ on the nitrogen atom.
questions.explanation_correct: The basicity of amines is due to the presence of a lone pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom. This lone pair can accept a proton, making the amine a basic compound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'lone pair of electrons'. The basicity of amines is not due to the presence of a single electron on the nitrogen atom, but rather a lone pair of electrons. The lone pair allows the amine to accept a proton, making it a basic compound.

questions.question_text: The general formula of a diazonium salt is ArN2+X-, and the process of its formation is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The process of forming a diazonium salt (ArN2+X-) from a primary aromatic amine is called diazotisation. This involves treating the amine with sodium nitrite (NaNO2) and hydrochloric acid (HCl) at 0-5°C, which replaces the amino group (-NH2) with the diazonium group (-N2+).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for the given question is 'diazotisation'. Diazotisation is the correct term for the process of forming a diazonium salt from a primary aromatic amine. It involves treating the amine with NaNO2 and HCl at low temperature to replace the amino group with the diazonium group. The general formula of the diazonium salt is ArN2+X-, where X- is the counterion.

questions.question_text: In the Hinsberg test, secondary amines react with benzenesulfonyl chloride to give a sulfonamide that is ___ in NaOH.
questions.explanation_correct: In the Hinsberg test, secondary amines react with benzenesulfonyl chloride to form a sulfonamide product that is insoluble in NaOH. This is because the sulfonamide contains a strong N-S bond that is not cleaved by the base, making the product insoluble.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that the sulfonamide product formed between a secondary amine and benzenesulfonyl chloride is insoluble in NaOH. This is because the N-S bond in the sulfonamide is not broken by the base. However, if the amine was a primary amine, the product would be soluble in NaOH as the N-H bond can be cleaved by the base.

questions.question_text: In the Gabriel synthesis, potassium phthalimide reacts with an alkyl halide followed by hydrolysis with ___ to give the primary amine.
questions.explanation_correct: The Gabriel synthesis involves the reaction of potassium phthalimide with an alkyl halide to form an N-alkylphthalimide. This is then hydrolyzed using either NaOH or hydrazine (N2H4) to produce the primary amine. Both of these reagents can cleave the phthalimide group, liberating the amine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Gabriel synthesis does not involve the use of ammonia (NH3) directly. Instead, it uses potassium phthalimide as an intermediate to introduce the amine group, which is then liberated using either NaOH or hydrazine (N2H4). The correct answer is either NaOH or hydrazine, as these reagents can hydrolyze the phthalimide group and release the primary amine.

questions.question_text: The coupling product of a diazonium salt with an amine or phenol contains the characteristic ___ linkage (-N=N-).
questions.explanation_correct: The coupling product of a diazonium salt with an amine or phenol contains the characteristic azo linkage (-N=N-) because the diazonium ion (-N≡N+) reacts with the nucleophilic amine or phenol to form this distinctive azo group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'azo', which refers to the characteristic (-N=N-) linkage formed when a diazonium salt couples with an amine or phenol. This azo linkage is a key feature of these coupling reactions, which are widely used to synthesize various colored organic compounds.

questions.question_text: Aniline is also known as ___ in IUPAC nomenclature.
questions.explanation_correct: Aniline is the IUPAC name for phenylamine, which is the common name for the organic compound with the formula C6H5NH2. The IUPAC nomenclature system uses 'phenylamine' to name this compound, as it has an amino group (-NH2) attached to a benzene ring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted IUPAC name for aniline is 'phenylamine' or 'benzenamine'. Aniline is not the IUPAC name, it is the common name for this compound. The IUPAC system uses systematic naming conventions to name organic compounds, and in this case, 'phenylamine' or 'benzenamine' is the correct IUPAC name for the compound with the formula C6H5NH2.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following in order of increasing basicity: (A) Aniline, (B) p-Nitroaniline, (C) p-Methylaniline, (D) Methylamine.
questions.explanation_correct: The order of increasing basicity is B (p-Nitroaniline), A (Aniline), C (p-Methylaniline), D (Methylamine). This is because the electron-withdrawing nitro group in p-Nitroaniline decreases the basicity, while the electron-donating methyl group in p-Methylaniline increases the basicity compared to aniline. Methylamine, being an aliphatic amine, has a more basic lone pair on nitrogen compared to the aromatic amines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be A (Aniline), C (p-Methylaniline), D (Methylamine), B (p-Nitroaniline). This is because the electron-withdrawing nitro group in p-Nitroaniline does not decrease the basicity as much as the incorrect answer suggests. The order should be based on the relative ability of the nitrogen lone pair to accept a proton, with aliphatic amines being more basic than aromatic amines.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following amines in order of increasing boiling point: (A) Trimethylamine, (B) Ethylamine, (C) Diethylamine, (D) Propylamine.
questions.explanation_correct: The order of increasing boiling point is: Trimethylamine (A) < Ethylamine (B) < Propylamine (D) < Diethylamine (C). This is because as the molecular weight and number of carbon atoms increases, the boiling point also increases due to stronger intermolecular forces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be A, B, C, D. This is because the boiling point does not solely depend on the number of carbon atoms. Branching and the presence of electronegative atoms like nitrogen also affect the intermolecular forces and hence the boiling point. Trimethylamine (A) has the lowest boiling point due to its compact structure and lack of long alkyl chains, while Diethylamine (C) has the highest boiling point due to stronger intermolecular forces between the larger ethyl groups.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following reactions of diazonium salts in order of the electronegativity of the substituent introduced: (A) Sandmeyer with CuCl/HCl (gives Cl), (B) Sandmeyer with CuBr/HBr (gives Br), (C) Balz-Schiemann (gives F), (D) Treatment with KI (gives I).
questions.explanation_correct: The order of the reactions is based on the electronegativity of the substituents introduced, which follows the order: I > Br > Cl > F. This is because iodine has the lowest electronegativity, followed by bromine, chlorine, and fluorine has the highest electronegativity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to arrange the reactions in the order A, B, C, D. This is because the Sandmeyer reaction with CuCl/HCl introduces chlorine, which has a higher electronegativity than the bromine introduced in the Sandmeyer reaction with CuBr/HBr. The Balz-Schiemann reaction introduces fluorine, which has the highest electronegativity, and the reaction with KI introduces iodine, which has the lowest electronegativity.

questions.question_text: How does the basicity of aliphatic amines differ from that of aromatic amines in terms of electron availability on nitrogen?

options.text: Aliphatic amines have delocalised lone pairs while aromatic amines have localised lone pairs
Aliphatic amines have localised lone pairs available for protonation while aromatic amines have lone pairs delocalised into the benzene ring
Both have equally available lone pairs
Aromatic amines have more available lone pairs due to resonance stabilisation

questions.explanation_correct: Aliphatic amines have localised lone pairs on nitrogen that are readily available for protonation, making them stronger bases. In aromatic amines like aniline, the lone pair is delocalised into the benzene ring through resonance, reducing its availability for accepting a proton and thus decreasing basicity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The key difference is that aliphatic amines have localised, available lone pairs while aromatic amines have delocalised lone pairs. Option A reverses this relationship. Option C is incorrect because the availability differs significantly. Option D is wrong because delocalisation in aromatic amines actually decreases lone pair availability and basicity.

questions.question_text: How does the Gabriel phthalimide synthesis differ from the Hoffmann bromamide degradation in terms of the carbon skeleton of the product?

options.text: Gabriel synthesis retains the same carbon count while Hoffmann degradation loses one carbon
Gabriel synthesis adds one carbon while Hoffmann degradation retains the same
Both methods retain the same carbon count

questions.explanation_correct: Gabriel phthalimide synthesis converts an alkyl halide to a primary amine with the same number of carbon atoms. Hoffmann bromamide degradation converts an amide to a primary amine with one fewer carbon atom, as the carbonyl carbon is lost during the reaction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A. Gabriel synthesis maintains the carbon skeleton of the alkyl halide in the amine product. Hoffmann degradation specifically involves loss of the carbonyl carbon from the amide, resulting in one fewer carbon. Options B, C, and D misrepresent how these reactions affect the carbon skeleton.

questions.question_text: How does the reaction of primary aromatic amines with nitrous acid differ from that of primary aliphatic amines in terms of product stability?

options.text: Primary aromatic amines form stable diazonium salts while primary aliphatic amines form unstable diazonium salts that decompose to alcohols
Primary aromatic amines form unstable products while primary aliphatic amines form stable diazonium salts
Both form equally stable diazonium salts
Both form unstable products that immediately decompose

questions.explanation_correct: Primary aromatic amines react with nitrous acid (NaNO2/HCl) at 0-5°C to form stable aromatic diazonium salts that can be isolated and used in further reactions. Primary aliphatic amines form unstable aliphatic diazonium salts that immediately decompose to alcohols with evolution of nitrogen gas, and cannot be isolated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A. The aromatic ring provides resonance stabilisation to the diazonium cation, making aromatic diazonium salts stable enough to isolate and use. Aliphatic diazonium salts lack this stabilisation and decompose immediately. Options B, C, and D incorrectly describe the relative stabilities of these intermediates.

questions.question_text: How does the Sandmeyer reaction differ from the Balz-Schiemann reaction in terms of the halogen introduced onto the aromatic ring?

options.text: Sandmeyer introduces Cl, Br, or CN while Balz-Schiemann specifically introduces F
Sandmeyer introduces F while Balz-Schiemann introduces Cl and Br
Sandmeyer introduces I while Balz-Schiemann introduces Br

questions.explanation_correct: Sandmeyer reactions use copper(I) halides (CuCl, CuBr) or CuCN to introduce Cl, Br, or CN groups onto the aromatic ring. The Balz-Schiemann reaction is specifically used to introduce fluorine using fluoroboric acid, as direct Sandmeyer-type conditions do not work well for fluorine introduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A. Sandmeyer reactions are versatile for introducing Cl, Br, and CN groups. The Balz-Schiemann reaction was developed specifically for introducing fluorine, which cannot be efficiently introduced via standard Sandmeyer conditions. Options B, C, and D misrepresent which halogens these reactions introduce.

questions.question_text: How does the product of the Hinsberg test differ between primary and secondary amines?

options.text: Primary amine products are soluble in NaOH while secondary amine products are insoluble in NaOH
Primary amine products are insoluble in NaOH while secondary amine products are soluble in NaOH
Both products are equally soluble in NaOH
Both products are insoluble in all solvents

questions.explanation_correct: When primary amines react with benzenesulfonyl chloride in the Hinsberg test, the product has an acidic N-H hydrogen that can be deprotonated by NaOH, making it soluble. Secondary amine products have no acidic N-H hydrogen (both hydrogens replaced by alkyl groups and the sulfonyl group), so they remain insoluble in NaOH.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A. The key is the presence of an acidic N-H in the primary amine product versus its absence in the secondary amine product. This N-H can be removed by base, forming a soluble salt. Secondary amine sulfonamides lack this acidic hydrogen and remain insoluble. Options B, C, and D incorrectly describe the solubility differences.

questions.question_text: An amine that liberates nitrogen gas when treated with nitrous acid at room temperature and forms an alcohol as the major product is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Primary aliphatic amines react with nitrous acid to form unstable aliphatic diazonium salts that immediately decompose with evolution of nitrogen gas to give alcohols. This behaviour is characteristic of primary aliphatic amines and distinguishes them from primary aromatic amines which form stable diazonium salts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B. Primary aromatic amines form stable diazonium salts that do not immediately decompose. Secondary amines form N-nitrosoamines (no N2 evolution or alcohol formation). Tertiary amines either don't react or form nitrite salts. Only primary aliphatic amines show this specific reaction pattern of immediate N2 liberation and alcohol formation.

questions.question_text: An amine that forms a foul-smelling isocyanide with chloroform and alcoholic KOH, and gives a white precipitate with bromine water is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: The foul-smelling isocyanide formation with CHCl3/KOH is the carbylamine test specific for primary amines. The white precipitate with bromine water indicates formation of 2,4,6-tribromoaniline, which is characteristic of aniline (primary aromatic amine). Together, these two tests confirm the compound is a primary aromatic amine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A. The carbylamine test is positive for all primary amines (both aliphatic and aromatic). However, only aromatic amines with an activating -NH2 group react with bromine water to give tribrominated products. Primary aliphatic amines would show only the carbylamine test, not the bromination. Secondary and tertiary amines do not give the carbylamine test.

questions.question_text: An amine that forms a yellow oily N-nitroso compound when treated with nitrous acid, but shows no reaction in the carbylamine test, is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Secondary amines react with nitrous acid to form yellow oily N-nitrosoamines (R2N-N=O). The negative carbylamine test confirms it is not a primary amine, as only primary amines give the carbylamine test. Tertiary amines do not form N-nitroso compounds. Therefore, the compound must be a secondary amine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B. Primary amines give the carbylamine test and form alcohols with nitrous acid, not N-nitroso compounds. Tertiary amines typically form soluble nitrite salts or do not react, not N-nitroso compounds. Quaternary ammonium salts do not have a lone pair and cannot react with nitrous acid. Only secondary amines show this specific combination of positive nitrous acid test (N-nitrosoamine formation) and negative carbylamine test.

questions.question_text: A nitrogen-containing compound with formula C6H5N(CH3)2 that shows basic properties and dissolves in dilute HCl is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: The formula C6H5N(CH3)2 shows a benzene ring (C6H5) with nitrogen bonded to two methyl groups. Since nitrogen is bonded to three carbon groups (one phenyl and two methyl) with no hydrogen on nitrogen, this is a tertiary aromatic amine (N,N-dimethylaniline). It shows basic properties due to the lone pair on nitrogen and forms salts with HCl.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C. Primary amines have the form RNH2, and secondary amines have R2NH—both require at least one H on nitrogen, which this compound lacks. The nitrogen is bonded to three carbon groups: the phenyl ring and two methyl groups, making it tertiary. Aromatic nitriles have the -CN group and do not show significant basicity or salt formation with dilute HCl like amines do.

questions.question_text: Priya is preparing for her ISC chemistry practical and needs to distinguish between aniline, N-methylaniline, and N,N-dimethylaniline. She performs the Hinsberg test with benzenesulfonyl chloride followed by treatment with NaOH. Which observation would confirm the presence of aniline?

options.text: The product remains insoluble in NaOH
No reaction occurs with benzenesulfonyl chloride

questions.explanation_correct: Aniline is a primary aromatic amine. In the Hinsberg test, it reacts with benzenesulfonyl chloride to form a sulfonamide with an acidic N-H hydrogen. This product dissolves in NaOH because the acidic hydrogen can be removed by the base. N-methylaniline (secondary) would give an insoluble product, and N,N-dimethylaniline (tertiary) would not react.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A. An insoluble product (option B) would indicate a secondary amine like N-methylaniline. No reaction (option C) would indicate a tertiary amine like N,N-dimethylaniline. Red colour formation (option D) is not a characteristic of the Hinsberg test. Only primary amines form sulfonamides that are soluble in NaOH due to the acidic N-H.

questions.question_text: Rohan, a Class 12 student, is synthesising chlorobenzene from aniline in his chemistry laboratory. He first converts aniline to benzenediazonium chloride at 0-5°C. What should be his next step according to the Sandmeyer reaction?

options.text: Heat the diazonium salt solution with water
Treat the diazonium salt with CuCl in the presence of HCl
Treat the diazonium salt with fluoroboric acid
Add the diazonium salt to phenol in alkaline medium

questions.explanation_correct: To prepare chlorobenzene from benzenediazonium chloride, Rohan should use the Sandmeyer reaction by treating the diazonium salt with copper(I) chloride (CuCl) in the presence of HCl. This replaces the diazonium group with chlorine to form chlorobenzene.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B. Heating with water (option A) would give phenol, not chlorobenzene. Fluoroboric acid (option C) is used in the Balz-Schiemann reaction to prepare fluorobenzene. Adding to phenol in alkaline medium (option D) is a coupling reaction to form azo dyes. Only treatment with CuCl/HCl gives the desired chlorobenzene product via the Sandmeyer mechanism.

questions.question_text: Meera wants to prepare pure primary amine from 1-bromobutane without any contamination from secondary or tertiary amines. Which method should she use?
questions.explanation_correct: Gabriel phthalimide synthesis is the best method to prepare pure primary amines from alkyl halides without secondary or tertiary amine contamination. The phthalimide nitrogen can only be alkylated once, ensuring only primary amine formation. Direct ammonolysis gives a mixture due to over-alkylation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B. Direct ammonolysis (option A) with 1-bromobutane would give a mixture of primary, secondary, tertiary amines and quaternary salts due to successive alkylation. Reduction with LiAlH4 (option C) is used for nitriles or amides, not alkyl halides. Hoffmann degradation (option D) requires an amide as starting material, not an alkyl halide. Only Gabriel synthesis ensures pure primary amine from alkyl halides.

questions.question_text: Arjun is performing a NEET chemistry experiment where he needs to selectively nitrate aniline at the para position while avoiding oxidation of the amino group. What protective strategy should he employ?

options.text: React aniline directly with concentrated HNO3/H2SO4
First acetylate aniline to form acetanilide, then nitrate, then hydrolyse
First convert aniline to diazonium salt, then nitrate
Dissolve aniline in NaOH before nitration

questions.explanation_correct: Aniline is highly susceptible to oxidation by the nitrating mixture. Arjun should first protect the amino group by acetylation to form acetanilide. This reduces the activating effect and prevents oxidation while directing nitration to the para position. After nitration, the acetyl group is removed by hydrolysis to regenerate the amino group, yielding p-nitroaniline.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B. Direct nitration (option A) would oxidise aniline and give a complex mixture with excessive ring substitution. Converting to diazonium salt (option C) is not done before nitration—diazonium salts are used for substitution reactions, not electrophilic aromatic substitution. Dissolving in NaOH (option D) would not protect the amino group from oxidation. Only acetylation provides the necessary protection while controlling the reaction.

questions.question_text: Riya is synthesising an orange-red azo dye for her chemistry project. She has prepared benzenediazonium chloride and needs to couple it with β-naphthol. In what medium should she perform this coupling reaction?

options.text: In pure organic solvent without any aqueous component

questions.explanation_correct: Azo coupling reactions between diazonium salts and phenols (like β-naphthol) are carried out in alkaline medium. The alkaline conditions convert the phenol to the more reactive phenoxide ion, which is a stronger nucleophile for the electrophilic diazonium cation, facilitating the coupling reaction to form the coloured azo compound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C. In strongly acidic medium (option A), phenol would not be deprotonated to form the reactive phenoxide nucleophile, and the coupling would be very slow or not occur. Neutral medium (option B) is also not optimal as phenoxide formation is favoured in base. Pure organic solvent (option D) is impractical as both the diazonium salt and phenoxide need to be in solution, which requires an aqueous component.

questions.question_text: Among the aliphatic amines methylamine, dimethylamine, and trimethylamine, which one is an exception to the expected trend of increasing basicity with increasing number of methyl groups in aqueous solution?

options.text: Methylamine is less basic than expected
Dimethylamine is less basic than expected
Trimethylamine is less basic than expected due to steric hindrance and reduced solvation
None shows exceptional behaviour; all follow the expected trend

questions.explanation_correct: While the +I effect of methyl groups increases electron density on nitrogen, trimethylamine is unexpectedly less basic than dimethylamine in aqueous solution. This is because the three bulky methyl groups cause steric hindrance to protonation and significantly reduce the solvation (stabilisation) of the trimethylammonium ion by water molecules, making the protonated form less stable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C. Methylamine and dimethylamine (options A and B) follow the expected trend of increasing basicity with methyl substitution due to the +I effect. The order in aqueous solution is (CH3)2NH > CH3NH2 > (CH3)3N > NH3, where trimethylamine breaks the expected pattern. Option D is incorrect because trimethylamine does show exceptional behaviour as an exception to the simple +I effect prediction.

questions.question_text: Although aniline is a weaker base than aliphatic amines, it readily undergoes electrophilic aromatic substitution. Which statement correctly explains this apparent exception?

options.text: The amino group withdraws electrons from the ring, making it reactive
The lone pair delocalisation that reduces basicity actually activates the ring for electrophilic attack at ortho/para positions
Aniline is not actually reactive towards electrophilic substitution
The benzene ring provides electrons to nitrogen, increasing reactivity

questions.explanation_correct: This is not truly contradictory but often confuses students. The lone pair on nitrogen in aniline is delocalised into the ring, reducing its availability for protonation (lower basicity). However, this same delocalisation increases electron density in the benzene ring, particularly at ortho and para positions, making the ring highly activated for electrophilic aromatic substitution. The effect operates in different directions for different properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B. The amino group is electron-donating, not withdrawing (option A is wrong). Aniline is actually highly reactive towards electrophilic substitution (option C is factually incorrect). The direction of electron flow is from nitrogen to the ring, not ring to nitrogen (option D reverses it). The key insight is that the same lone pair delocalisation decreases basicity but increases ring reactivity—seemingly opposite effects from the same electronic phenomenon.

questions.question_text: Diazonium salts are generally unstable, yet aromatic diazonium salts can be stored at low temperatures. What is the exception that allows this unusual stability?

options.text: The presence of the halide counterion
Resonance stabilisation of the diazonium cation by the aromatic ring
Strong ionic bonding in the crystal lattice
Formation of hydrogen bonds with water

questions.explanation_correct: Aromatic diazonium salts are exceptional among diazonium compounds in their relative stability. The aromatic ring can delocalise positive charge through resonance, stabilising the diazonium cation. This resonance stabilisation is not available to aliphatic diazonium salts, which decompose immediately. Combined with low temperature (0-5°C), this allows aromatic diazonium salts to be isolated and used in synthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B. The halide counterion (option A) is present in both aromatic and aliphatic diazonium salts but doesn't explain the stability difference. Ionic bonding strength (option C) doesn't distinguish aromatic from aliphatic diazonium salts. Hydrogen bonding with water (option D) would not stabilise a cationic species and is not the key factor. Only resonance stabilisation by the aromatic ring explains why aromatic diazonium salts are stable enough to isolate while aliphatic ones are not.

questions.question_text: Why is ethylamine classified as a stronger base than aniline in aqueous solution and not as a weaker base?

options.text: Because ethylamine has higher molecular mass
Because the lone pair on nitrogen in ethylamine is localised and readily available for protonation, while in aniline it is delocalised into the benzene ring

questions.explanation_correct: Ethylamine is classified as a stronger base than aniline because basicity depends on the availability of the nitrogen lone pair for protonation. In ethylamine (aliphatic amine), the lone pair is localised on nitrogen and readily available. In aniline, the lone pair is delocalised through resonance into the benzene ring, making it less available for accepting a proton, thus reducing basicity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B. Molecular mass (option A) does not determine basicity—it's about electron availability. Ethylamine is aliphatic, not aromatic (option C is factually wrong). While aniline does have an electron-donating -NH2 group (option D), this doesn't explain why it's a weaker base than ethylamine. The key reason is the difference in lone pair localisation: localised in ethylamine (more basic) versus delocalised in aniline (less basic).

questions.question_text: Why is p-nitroaniline classified as a much weaker base than aniline and not as a stronger base?

options.text: Because the nitro group donates electrons by +I effect
Because the nitro group is a strong electron-withdrawing group that reduces electron density on nitrogen through -I and -M effects
Because p-nitroaniline has higher molecular weight
Because the nitro group increases the availability of the lone pair on nitrogen

questions.explanation_correct: p-Nitroaniline is classified as a much weaker base than aniline because the nitro group (-NO2) is a strong electron-withdrawing group. It withdraws electron density from the benzene ring and the nitrogen atom through both inductive effect (-I) and mesomeric effect (-M). This further reduces the already limited availability of the nitrogen lone pair for protonation, making p-nitroaniline significantly less basic than aniline.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B. The nitro group is electron-withdrawing, not electron-donating (option A is wrong—it shows -I and -M effects, not +I). Molecular weight (option C) is irrelevant to basicity. The nitro group decreases, not increases, lone pair availability (option D is opposite to reality). The correct reasoning is that the electron-withdrawing nature of the nitro group further destabilises the lone pair and reduces basicity beyond the already weak basicity of aniline.

questions.question_text: Why are diazonium salts classified as synthetic intermediates rather than as stable final products?

options.text: Because they are highly coloured and aesthetically unpleasing
Because they have low molecular weight
Because the N≡N+ group is a good leaving group that allows versatile substitution reactions to introduce various functional groups onto the aromatic ring
Because they are too expensive to use as final products

questions.explanation_correct: Diazonium salts are classified as synthetic intermediates because the diazonium group (N≡N+) is an excellent leaving group. This allows the diazonium nitrogen to be replaced by a wide variety of nucleophiles (Cl, Br, I, CN, OH, F, H) through reactions like Sandmeyer, Balz-Schiemann, and others. This versatility makes them invaluable intermediates for introducing substituents that cannot be easily introduced by direct electrophilic substitution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C. Colour (option A) is not a reason for classification as intermediates—many final products are coloured. Molecular weight (option B) is irrelevant to their role in synthesis. Cost (option D) is not the determining factor. The key reason is chemical: the diazonium group is such an excellent leaving group that these salts enable transformations otherwise difficult to achieve, making them strategic intermediates rather than target molecules in synthesis.
